name: Maya Desai
description: Maya Desai is a 33-year-old UX researcher in Seattle who treats reading as both inquiry and community-building. Analytical yet warm, she gravitates toward literary and speculative fiction with social commentary, translated works, and South Asian diaspora narratives—balancing heavier reads with cozy mysteries and graphic novels as palate cleansers. She splits formats between a Kindle for weekday commutes, library hardcovers on weekends, and audiobooks during long walks. Maya meticulously captures highlights, syncing them to Obsidian via Readwise to maintain a searchable commonplace book. Her shelves are arranged by “mood and geography,” and she uses color-coded tabs for themes like craft, character, culture, and quotables. Online, Maya moderates a Discord book club and hosts monthly Zoom salons where she sets clear discussion norms (spoiler protocols, content notes, and equitable speaking time). She writes concise, spoiler-light mini-reviews on StoryGraph and Instagram, focusing on questions a book raises rather than judgments alone. Annual goals keep her reading adventurous: at least 50 titles, 30% translated, and a focus month for Women in Translation. She seeks out independent bookstores when traveling, trades recs with booksellers, and volunteers locally with a literacy nonprofit. Her facilitation style is inclusive and question-driven—she sees herself as a curator of conversation, not a critic. A methodical morning reader and a long-form Sunday afternoon finisher, Maya pairs teas with settings (oolong for East Asia, masala chai for Indian lit) and loves designing themed buddy reads across time zones. She values respectful debate, accessible materials, and joyful nerdery—treating each new book as a chance to expand empathy and pattern recognition.
example_behaviours: Hosts a monthly themed Zoom salon with spoiler-tag protocols and rotating co-moderators
Maintains an Obsidian “constellation” map linking books by theme, setting, and motif
Uses color-coded tabs for annotations (craft, character, culture, quotables)
Tracks mood and pacing metrics on StoryGraph to guide future picks
Pairs specific teas with the geographic setting of a book
Runs quarterly buddy reads across time zones with shared reading sprints
Writes 500-word, spoiler-light mini-reviews and posts discussion questions
Visits an independent bookstore in every city she travels to and buys one staff-pick
Volunteers at a local literacy nonprofit, organizing community book swaps
Keeps a personal “no-buy” month using only library holds and her TBR
Records 3-minute voice notes after dense chapters to capture fresh reactions
Designs custom bookmarks featuring favorite quotes and gift-wraps them for swap partners
